column2:
I AM SIGNING FOR JOHNNY DEPP ONLY AGAINSET HIS EX WIFE AMBER HEARD FOR VIOLENCE ON 
 JOHNNY DEPP
column26: U​.​S. Congress: Change "Violence Against Women Act" to "Violence Against Partner" Act
column33: U​.​S. Congress: Change "Violence Against Women Act" to "Violence Against Partner" Act
column34:
In light of the realities around domestic violence against men that have come to light out of the Johnny Depp Vs. Amber Heard trial, many people across the world are coming to realize just how difficult it is for men to come forward and report domestic violence perpetrated by their spouse, particularly a female spouse.

The trial has showed the world how men who've been brought up to "never hit a woman" have that belief used against them by women who physically attack, punch, kick, throw things, or use objects as weapons to injure their male partners. The abuse, as revealed in Depp's case as one example, often includes exploitation of the partner's financial resources, belittling and demeaning their male partner, and using any weaknesses such as addictions to control and further shame their partner.

This petition is to tell the U.S. Congress that the Violence Against Women Act is named in such a way that furthers the stigma for men who are suffering under domestic violence. It implies that men can't be victims of violence by women, and further implies that the U.S. government does not care about domestic violence victims if they are male.

We are appealing to Congress, at the very least, to rename this law to the "Violence Against Partner" Act, or at the very best to reword the language throughout the act so that it is gender neutral and provides help and assistance to all victims of domestic and partner violence regardless of gender.
column36: U​.​S. Congress: Change "Violence Against Women Act" to "Violence Against Partner" Act
column125: U​.​S. Congress: Change "Violence Against Women Act" to "Violence Against Partner" Act
column126: U​.​S. Congress: Change "Violence Against Women Act" to "Violence Against Partner" Act

column2: Statistics reflect men can be victims of domestic violence at the hands of women just as easily as women at the hands of men. The law should reflect that and not discriminate based on the sex of victim or perpetrator.

column2:
This is about violent type people being able get away with violence in so many different ways.
It has no gender.
